elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Two novel Cu-based coordination polymers [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(HPyImDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]·(NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HPyImDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) containing the 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC) ligand have been solvothermally synthesized. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a three dimensional framework with 1D rhombic channels, which can be simplified into a novel (3, 4)-connected network with Schläfli symbol of (6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.14<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is one dimensional chain which packed with each other via π–π and hydrogen-bonding interactions to construct a three dimensional supramolecular structure. As the first example related to Cu (I) and Cu (I, II) coordination polymers based on H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC ligands, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are further studied by elemental analyses, IR spectroscopy and thermogravimetric analyses.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two novel Cu-based coordination polymers [Cu5(HPyImDC)4]⋅(NH4)3 (1) and [Cu3(H2O)2(HPyImDC)2(C3N2H10)] (2) containing the 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate (H3PyImDC) ligand have been solvothermally synthesized. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 exhibits a three dimensional framework with 1D rhombic channels, which can be simplified into a novel (3, 4)-connected network with Schläfli symbol of (62.144)(62.8)4. Compound 2 is one dimensional chain which packed with each other via π-π and hydrogen-bonding interactions to construct a three dimensional supramolecular structure. As the first example related to Cu (I) and Cu (I, II) coordination polymers based on H3PyImDC ligands, compounds 1 and 2 are further studied by elemental analyses, IR spectroscopy and thermogravimetric analyses.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">Structural views of the two coordination polymers [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(HPyImDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·(NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HPyImDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> as the first example related to Cu (I) and Cu (I, II) coordination polymers based on H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC ligands are both constructed from 1D rhombic chains. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a three dimensional framework, and compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is constructed by 1D chains via hydrogen-bonding interactions to form 3D supramolecular structure.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link id="lk0015" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Structural views of the two coordination polymers [Cu5(HPyImDC)4⋅(NH4)3] (1) and [Cu3(H2O)2(HPyImDC)2(C3N2H10)] (2). Compounds 1 and 2 as the first example related to Cu (I) and Cu (I, II) coordination polymers based on H3PyImDC ligands are both constructed from 1D rhombic chains. Compound 1 exhibits a three dimensional framework, and compound 2 is constructed by 1D chains via hydrogen-bonding interactions to form 3D supramolecular structure.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:link id="lk0015" locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0050" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="u0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0090" view="all">Two coordination polymers constructed from imidazole-based dicarboxylate ligands containing pyridyl group</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a 3D framework formed by the corner-sharing 1D chains.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0100" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> presents a 3D supramolecular structure via π–π and hydrogen-bonding interactions.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ Two coordination polymers constructed from imidazole-based dicarboxylate ligands containing pyridyl group   ⋅ Compound 1 exhibits a 3D framework formed by the corner-sharing 1D chains.   ⋅ Compound 2 presents a 3D supramolecular structure via π-π and hydrogen-bonding interactions.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0090" view="all">Two coordination polymers constructed from imidazole-based dicarboxylate ligands containing pyridyl group</ce:para><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a 3D framework formed by the corner-sharing 1D chains.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> presents a 3D supramolecular structure via π–π and hydrogen-bonding interactions.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">During the past decade, design and synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers have been rapidly developed, not only for the enormous variety of intriguing structural topologies but also for the great potential in applications as pertaining to microporosity, catalysis, magnetism and fluorescence . An effective and easy route for the synthesis of MOFs is still the self-assembly of multifunctional organic ligands and metal ions under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions . Thus, much attention has been paid to the choice of ligand functionalities. Heterocyclic carboxylic acids, as a type of ligand functionality, have become ideal ligands for constructing MOFs due to their diversities in coordination modes, such as 4,5-imidazole dicarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>ImDC) . Compared with H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>ImDC, its derivative with different substitution groups like methyl, ethyl or pyridyl at the 2-position of the imidazole ring, has rarely been explored . Our group and others have been devoted to exploring the coordination modes of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>ImDC and its derivatives with different metal centers. So far, a series of coordination polymers with variety of structures based on these ligands have been synthesized .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Two coordination polymers constructed from imidazole-based dicarboxylate ligands containing pyridyl group

Compound 1 exhibits a 3D framework formed by the corner-sharing 1D chains.

Compound 2 presents a 3D supramolecular structure via π-π and hydrogen-bonding interactions.

During the past decade, design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers have been rapidly developed, not only for the enormous variety of intriguing structural topologies but also for the great potential in applications as pertaining to microporosity, catalysis, magnetism and fluorescence . An effective and easy route for the synthesis of MOFs is still the self-assembly of multifunctional organic ligands and metal ions under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions . Thus, much attention has been paid to the choice of ligand functionalities. Heterocyclic carboxylic acids, as a type of ligand functionality, have become ideal ligands for constructing MOFs due to their diversities in coordination modes, such as 4,5-imidazole dicarboxylic acid (H3ImDC) . Compared with H3ImDC, its derivative with different substitution groups like methyl, ethyl or pyridyl at the 2-position of the imidazole ring, has rarely been explored . Our group and others have been devoted to exploring the coordination modes of H3ImDC and its derivatives with different metal centers. So far, a series of coordination polymers with variety of structures based on these ligands have been synthesized .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Herein, we choose 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC) as the organic ligand for reaction with Cu ions to construct novel MOFs based on the following reasons: (1) H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC can form various coordination modes through partially or fully deprotonated to H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and PyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> by controlling the pH values of reaction system. (2) H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC possesses multiple coordinate sites involving one pyridine N atom, two imidazole N atoms and four carboxylate O atoms, moreover, the different coordinate sites display different coordination activities. (3) There are a limited number of MOFs based on the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC ligand .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Herein, we choose 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate (H3PyImDC) as the organic ligand for reaction with Cu ions to construct novel MOFs based on the following reasons: (1) H3PyImDC can form various coordination modes through partially or fully deprotonated to H2PyImDC-, HPyImDC2- and PyImDC3- by controlling the pH values of reaction system. (2) H3PyImDC possesses multiple coordinate sites involving one pyridine N atom, two imidazole N atoms and four carboxylate O atoms, moreover, the different coordinate sites display different coordination activities. (3) There are a limited number of MOFs based on the H3PyImDC ligand .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Taking all of this into consideration, we report the syntheses and structures of two Cu-MOFs, [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(HPyImDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·(NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HPyImDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), which represent the first example of Cu (I) and Cu (I, II) MOFs assembled from H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Taking all of this into consideration, we report the syntheses and structures of two Cu-MOFs, [Cu5(HPyImDC)4⋅(NH4)3] (1) and [Cu3(H2O)2(HPyImDC)2(C3N2H10)] (2), which represent the first example of Cu (I) and Cu (I, II) MOFs assembled from H3PyImDC ligand.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Accordingly, the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC was prepared according to reported procedures . All other reagents were unprocessed as received from commercial sources. The reaction of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC, Cu(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, in a N,N′-dimethylformamide solution in the presence of NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O afforded the synthesis of pale yellow crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has been solvothermally synthesized by the reaction of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC and CuI in a N,N′-dimethylformamide/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O solution in the presence of 1,2-diaminopropane (see supporting information). The detailed crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for the two compounds are listed in Tables S1 and S2, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Accordingly, the H3PyImDC was prepared according to reported procedures . All other reagents were unprocessed as received from commercial sources. The reaction of H3PyImDC, Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O, in a N,N'-dimethylformamide solution in the presence of NH3⋅H2O afforded the synthesis of pale yellow crystals of 1. Compound 2 has been solvothermally synthesized by the reaction of H3PyImDC and CuI in a N,N'-dimethylformamide/H2O solution in the presence of 1,2-diaminopropane (see supporting information). The detailed crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for the two compounds are listed in Tables S1 and S2, respectively.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic system space group <ce:italic>Fddd</ce:italic> with a 3D framework and the coordination environment around Cu(I) ions is shown in Fig. S1. There is one crystallographically unique HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anion and two unique Cu(I) ions (Cu1 and Cu2) in the asymmetric unit. In each independent HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand, the pyridyl nitrogen atom coordinates to one Cu2 atom and the imidazoledicarboxylate groups chelate two Cu1 atoms in a bis-bidentate fashion through one oxygen atom and one adjacent nitrogen atom. The Cu1 atom displays see-saw like [CuN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] geometry, which coordinates with two HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions in a bidentate fashion through N-, O-heterocoordination (Cu1–O1, 2.40(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu1–O3A, 2.445<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu1–N1, 1.914(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu1–N2A, 1.915(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The Cu2 atom with tetrahedral [CuN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] geometry connects to four N atoms (Cu2–N3, 2.059(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) from four pyridyl groups. The unique arrangement modes cause both of the Cu1 and Cu2 to lie in distorted coordination geometry.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system space group Fddd with a 3D framework and the coordination environment around Cu(I) ions is shown in Fig. S1. There is one crystallographically unique HPyImDC2- anion and two unique Cu(I) ions (Cu1 and Cu2) in the asymmetric unit. In each independent HPyImDC2- ligand, the pyridyl nitrogen atom coordinates to one Cu2 atom and the imidazoledicarboxylate groups chelate two Cu1 atoms in a bis-bidentate fashion through one oxygen atom and one adjacent nitrogen atom. The Cu1 atom displays see-saw like [CuN2O2] geometry, which coordinates with two HPyImDC2- anions in a bidentate fashion through N-, O-heterocoordination (Cu1-O1, 2.40(3)Å; Cu1-O3A, 2.445Å; Cu1-N1, 1.914(3)Å; Cu1-N2A, 1.915(3)Å). The Cu2 atom with tetrahedral [CuN4] geometry connects to four N atoms (Cu2-N3, 2.059(3)Å) from four pyridyl groups. The unique arrangement modes cause both of the Cu1 and Cu2 to lie in distorted coordination geometry.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the Cu1 atoms and HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions are arranged in a line to form 1D chains {-Cu-HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>-Cu-} along the [010] direction, which are further interconnected by the Cu2 atoms to build 1D rhombic chains along the [101] direction (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). The corner-sharing 1D chains are alternately linked together by Cu2 atoms in different directions to generate a 3D open framework (b), which displays rhombic openings with an approximate diameter of 13.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (point-to-point and not including van der Waals radii) along [010] direction (c). The uncoordinated ammonium ions serve as guest molecules in the channels and are protonated in order to balance the negative charge provided by framework. Excluding the guest molecules, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a 3898<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> potential solvent volume estimated by PLATON , accounting for 35.2% of the total cell volume.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In compound 1, the Cu1 atoms and HPyImDC2- anions are arranged in a line to form 1D chains {-Cu-HPyImDC2--Cu-} along the [010] direction, which are further interconnected by the Cu2 atoms to build 1D rhombic chains along the [101] direction (a). The corner-sharing 1D chains are alternately linked together by Cu2 atoms in different directions to generate a 3D open framework (b), which displays rhombic openings with an approximate diameter of 13.7×6.2Å (point-to-point and not including van der Waals radii) along [010] direction (c). The uncoordinated ammonium ions serve as guest molecules in the channels and are protonated in order to balance the negative charge provided by framework. Excluding the guest molecules, compound 1 has a 3898Å3 potential solvent volume estimated by PLATON , accounting for 35.2% of the total cell volume.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">To better understand the structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the framework was simplified by TOPOS 4.0 as shown in d, in which the HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands act as 3-connected nodes and the Cu2 atom acts as 4-connected nodes. Therefore, the framework of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be described as a novel binodal (3, 4)-connected network with Schläfli symbol of (6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.14<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>. To the best of our knowledge, many MOFs of (3, 4)-connected networks have been reported, such as <ce:bold>pto</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>bor</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>ctn</ce:bold>
. And compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a novel (3, 4)-connected network constructed by triangular 3-connected and tetrahedral 4-connected nodes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To better understand the structure of compound 1, the framework was simplified by TOPOS 4.0 as shown in d, in which the HPyImDC2- ligands act as 3-connected nodes and the Cu2 atom acts as 4-connected nodes. Therefore, the framework of compound 1 can be described as a novel binodal (3, 4)-connected network with Schläfli symbol of (62.144)(62.8)4. To the best of our knowledge, many MOFs of (3, 4)-connected networks have been reported, such as pto, bor, and ctn . And compound 1 is a novel (3, 4)-connected network constructed by triangular 3-connected and tetrahedral 4-connected nodes.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>C2/c</ce:italic>. In the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, there are two crystallographically independent Cu(I) and Cu(II) ions. The HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anion adopts the same coordination mode as in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> which bridges two Cu(I) ions and one Cu(II) ion. As shown in Fig. S2, the Cu(I) ion, with distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, is coordinated to two HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions in a bidentate fashion through N-, O-heterocoordination (Cu1–N1, 1.894(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu1–N2A, 1.888(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu1–O1, 2.534<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu1–O4A, 2.506<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The Cu(II) ion adopts an octahedral coordination sphere in contrast to the Cu(I) ion. The Cu(II) ion is surrounded by four N atoms from two HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions, one 1,2-diaminopropane ligand, and two O atoms from two terminal water molecules (Cu2–N4, 2.032<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu2–N3, 2.044<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu2–O1W, 2.533<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The oxidation states of Cu ions are confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Fig. S3). Furthermore, Cu(I) ions and HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions are arranged in a line to form 1D chains {-Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>-HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>-Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>-} (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>), and two chains are interconnected by the Cu(II) ions to build a 1D rhombic chains along the [110] direction (b). Inside the chains, π–π interactions exist since the distance between two parallel HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands is 3.849<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (c).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. In the structure of 2, there are two crystallographically independent Cu(I) and Cu(II) ions. The HPyImDC2- anion adopts the same coordination mode as in compound 1 which bridges two Cu(I) ions and one Cu(II) ion. As shown in Fig. S2, the Cu(I) ion, with distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, is coordinated to two HPyImDC2- anions in a bidentate fashion through N-, O-heterocoordination (Cu1-N1, 1.894(3)Å; Cu1-N2A, 1.888(3)Å; Cu1-O1, 2.534Å; Cu1-O4A, 2.506Å). The Cu(II) ion adopts an octahedral coordination sphere in contrast to the Cu(I) ion. The Cu(II) ion is surrounded by four N atoms from two HPyImDC2- anions, one 1,2-diaminopropane ligand, and two O atoms from two terminal water molecules (Cu2-N4, 2.032Å; Cu2-N3, 2.044Å; Cu2-O1W, 2.533Å). The oxidation states of Cu ions are confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Fig. S3). Furthermore, Cu(I) ions and HPyImDC2- anions are arranged in a line to form 1D chains {-CuI-HPyImDC2--CuI-} (a), and two chains are interconnected by the Cu(II) ions to build a 1D rhombic chains along the [110] direction (b). Inside the chains, π-π interactions exist since the distance between two parallel HPyImDC2- ligands is 3.849Å (c).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">In compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands adopt the same coordination mode to the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, but varied in dimensional structure. Structural analysis reveals that the coordination sites of Cu(II) ion are occupied by the terminal water molecule and the 1,2-diaminopropane molecules and fail to link the 1D chains to a higher-dimensional structure. However, the 1D chains can be extended to a 3D supramolecular structure through π–π interactions and hydrogen bonding interactions (d). The hydrogen bonding interactions occur between the terminal water molecules and HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions, which link the adjacent 1D chains to generate a 3D supramolecular structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In compound 2, the HPyImDC2- ligands adopt the same coordination mode to the compound 1, but varied in dimensional structure. Structural analysis reveals that the coordination sites of Cu(II) ion are occupied by the terminal water molecule and the 1,2-diaminopropane molecules and fail to link the 1D chains to a higher-dimensional structure. However, the 1D chains can be extended to a 3D supramolecular structure through π-π interactions and hydrogen bonding interactions (d). The hydrogen bonding interactions occur between the terminal water molecules and HPyImDC2- anions, which link the adjacent 1D chains to generate a 3D supramolecular structure.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were synthesized under similar conditions and exhibited the similarities and differences in structures. Both compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contain {-Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>-HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>-Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>-} chains, the difference is that the 3D framework of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is constructed by 1D chains and Cu2 atoms, while the 1D chains in compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are linked via π–π and hydrogen-bonding interactions to generate a 3D supramolecular structure. Besides the influence of the nature of the Cu centers and the organic ligands, the introduction of ammonium ions and 1,2-diaminopropane can also play a crucial role in the assembly process. The ammonium ions may just act as deprotonation reagent and balance the charges of the negative framework of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the 1,2-diaminopropane molecules participate in the coordination with Cu ions. Thus, in the reaction system of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the coordination of the N atoms of 1,2-diaminopropane competes with the N atom of pyridyl ring, which decreases the opportunity of pyridyl N to participate in the coordination and finally lead to 1D structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized under similar conditions and exhibited the similarities and differences in structures. Both compounds 1 and 2 contain {-CuI-HPyImDC2--CuI-} chains, the difference is that the 3D framework of compound 1 is constructed by 1D chains and Cu2 atoms, while the 1D chains in compound 2 are linked via π-π and hydrogen-bonding interactions to generate a 3D supramolecular structure. Besides the influence of the nature of the Cu centers and the organic ligands, the introduction of ammonium ions and 1,2-diaminopropane can also play a crucial role in the assembly process. The ammonium ions may just act as deprotonation reagent and balance the charges of the negative framework of compound 1. For compound 2, the 1,2-diaminopropane molecules participate in the coordination with Cu ions. Thus, in the reaction system of compound 2, the coordination of the N atoms of 1,2-diaminopropane competes with the N atom of pyridyl ring, which decreases the opportunity of pyridyl N to participate in the coordination and finally lead to 1D structure.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibit similar IR absorbances around 1600–1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, which are ascribed to the vibrations of the C–C and C–N bonds in the pyridyl and imidazoledicarboxylate groups. Around 3500–2500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, the band of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is different with compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
. The bands between 3454<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and 3264<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> are associated with the hydrogen bonding interactions of carboxylic acid in the structure of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (Fig. S6) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit similar IR absorbances around 1600-1000cm-1, which are ascribed to the vibrations of the C-C and C-N bonds in the pyridyl and imidazoledicarboxylate groups. Around 3500-2500cm-1, the band of compound 2 is different with compound 1 . The bands between 3454cm-1 and 3264cm-1 are associated with the hydrogen bonding interactions of carboxylic acid in the structure of compound 2 (Fig. S6) .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0060" view="all">It is very interesting that the Cu(I) compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was prepared by Cu(II) salt and Cu(I,II) compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was prepared by Cu(I) salt. As the reduction of Cu(II) is sensitive to the reaction temperature and pH, Cu(II) is prone to be reduced to Cu(I) under the right condition (appropriate temperature and pH) . In the preparation of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the Cu(II) ions are reduced in the mixed systems containing NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL) at 140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. For the same reason, Cu(I) is apt to be oxidized to Cu(II). In the preparation of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the partial Cu(I) ions are oxidized in the mixed systems containing 1,2-diaminopropane (80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL) at 140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is very interesting that the Cu(I) compound 1 was prepared by Cu(II) salt and Cu(I,II) compound 2 was prepared by Cu(I) salt. As the reduction of Cu(II) is sensitive to the reaction temperature and pH, Cu(II) is prone to be reduced to Cu(I) under the right condition (appropriate temperature and pH) . In the preparation of compound 1, the Cu(II) ions are reduced in the mixed systems containing NH3⋅H2O (40μL) at 140°C. For the same reason, Cu(I) is apt to be oxidized to Cu(II). In the preparation of compound 2, the partial Cu(I) ions are oxidized in the mixed systems containing 1,2-diaminopropane (80μL) at 140°C.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The thermal stabilities of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are investigated through TGA experiments in the temperature range of 35–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C as shown in Fig. S7. An initial weight loss of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> below 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be attributed to the removal of N, N-dimethylformamide on the surface of the compounds. Upon further heating the organic ligand and the ammonium ions start to decompose and exhibit a weight loss of 73.30% between 165 and 393<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (calcd: 75.86%). The final product of 25.86% is attributed to the formation of CuO powder.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The thermal stabilities of compounds 1 and 2 are investigated through TGA experiments in the temperature range of 35-800°C as shown in Fig. S7. An initial weight loss of compound 1 below 150°C can be attributed to the removal of N, N-dimethylformamide on the surface of the compounds. Upon further heating the organic ligand and the ammonium ions start to decompose and exhibit a weight loss of 73.30% between 165 and 393°C (calcd: 75.86%). The final product of 25.86% is attributed to the formation of CuO powder.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the first step weight loss of 3.75% below 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be attributed to the removal of water molecules (calcd: 4.70%). The second weight loss that occurred from 273 to 462<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (68.38%) can be attributed to the decomposition of the 1,2-diaminopropane and the HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand (calcd: 70.24%). The final residuals of 30.85% are attributed to the formation of CuO powder.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: For compound 2, the first step weight loss of 3.75% below 273°C can be attributed to the removal of water molecules (calcd: 4.70%). The second weight loss that occurred from 273 to 462°C (68.38%) can be attributed to the decomposition of the 1,2-diaminopropane and the HPyImDC2- ligand (calcd: 70.24%). The final residuals of 30.85% are attributed to the formation of CuO powder.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0075" view="all">In conclusion, we have successfully constructed two novel Cu-containing coordination polymers based on the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC ligand. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of 1D chains that connect to each other through the Cu2 atoms generating a 3D network with 1D channels. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, with a 3D supramolecular structure, is constructed by π–π interactions and hydrogen bonding interactions. We focused our attention on the coordination polymers built by using the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC ligand in the presence of Cu centers and investigated the influence of the secondary ligand on the construction of frameworks. It was found that the coordination ability of the organic ligand has a significant influence on the resulting structure of the coordination polymers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have successfully constructed two novel Cu-containing coordination polymers based on the H3PyImDC ligand. Compound 1 consists of 1D chains that connect to each other through the Cu2 atoms generating a 3D network with 1D channels. Compound 2, with a 3D supramolecular structure, is constructed by π-π interactions and hydrogen bonding interactions. We focused our attention on the coordination polymers built by using the H3PyImDC ligand in the presence of Cu centers and investigated the influence of the secondary ligand on the construction of frameworks. It was found that the coordination ability of the organic ligand has a significant influence on the resulting structure of the coordination polymers.

CCDC 897189-897190 containing the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif, Synthesis of compounds 1 and 2, Single-crystal structure analysis, Powder XRD patterns, XPS, IR spectra, and TG curve, as well as some structure views of the compounds can be found online at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2015.01.010.

cln_elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the Cu1 atoms and HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions are arranged in a line to form 1D chains {-Cu-HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>-Cu-} along the [010] direction, which are further interconnected by the Cu2 atoms to build 1D rhombic chains along the [101] direction (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). The corner-sharing 1D chains are alternately linked together by Cu2 atoms in different directions to generate a 3D open framework (b), which displays rhombic openings with an approximate diameter of 13.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (point-to-point and not including van der Waals radii) along [010] direction (c). The uncoordinated ammonium ions serve as guest molecules in the channels and are protonated in order to balance the negative charge provided by framework. Excluding the guest molecules, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a 3898<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> potential solvent volume estimated by PLATON , accounting for 35.2% of the total cell volume.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>C2/c</ce:italic>. In the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, there are two crystallographically independent Cu(I) and Cu(II) ions. The HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anion adopts the same coordination mode as in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> which bridges two Cu(I) ions and one Cu(II) ion. As shown in Fig. S2, the Cu(I) ion, with distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, is coordinated to two HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions in a bidentate fashion through N-, O-heterocoordination (Cu1–N1, 1.894(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu1–N2A, 1.888(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu1–O1, 2.534<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu1–O4A, 2.506<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The Cu(II) ion adopts an octahedral coordination sphere in contrast to the Cu(I) ion. The Cu(II) ion is surrounded by four N atoms from two HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions, one 1,2-diaminopropane ligand, and two O atoms from two terminal water molecules (Cu2–N4, 2.032<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu2–N3, 2.044<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu2–O1W, 2.533<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The oxidation states of Cu ions are confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Fig. S3). Furthermore, Cu(I) ions and HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions are arranged in a line to form 1D chains {-Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>-HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>-Cu<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>-} (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>), and two chains are interconnected by the Cu(II) ions to build a 1D rhombic chains along the [110] direction (b). Inside the chains, π–π interactions exist since the distance between two parallel HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligands is 3.849<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (c).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The thermal stabilities of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are investigated through TGA experiments in the temperature range of 35–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C as shown in Fig. S7. An initial weight loss of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> below 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be attributed to the removal of N, N-dimethylformamide on the surface of the compounds. Upon further heating the organic ligand and the ammonium ions start to decompose and exhibit a weight loss of 73.30% between 165 and 393<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (calcd: 75.86%). The final product of 25.86% is attributed to the formation of CuO powder.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the first step weight loss of 3.75% below 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be attributed to the removal of water molecules (calcd: 4.70%). The second weight loss that occurred from 273 to 462<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (68.38%) can be attributed to the decomposition of the 1,2-diaminopropane and the HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand (calcd: 70.24%). The final residuals of 30.85% are attributed to the formation of CuO powder.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
In compound 1, the Cu1 atoms and HPyImDC2- anions are arranged in a line to form 1D chains {-Cu-HPyImDC2--Cu-} along the [010] direction, which are further interconnected by the Cu2 atoms to build 1D rhombic chains along the [101] direction (a). The corner-sharing 1D chains are alternately linked together by Cu2 atoms in different directions to generate a 3D open framework (b), which displays rhombic openings with an approximate diameter of 13.7×6.2Å (point-to-point and not including van der Waals radii) along [010] direction (c). The uncoordinated ammonium ions serve as guest molecules in the channels and are protonated in order to balance the negative charge provided by framework. Excluding the guest molecules, compound 1 has a 3898Å3 potential solvent volume estimated by PLATON , accounting for 35.2% of the total cell volume.

Single crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. In the structure of 2, there are two crystallographically independent Cu(I) and Cu(II) ions. The HPyImDC2- anion adopts the same coordination mode as in compound 1 which bridges two Cu(I) ions and one Cu(II) ion. As shown in Fig. S2, the Cu(I) ion, with distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, is coordinated to two HPyImDC2- anions in a bidentate fashion through N-, O-heterocoordination (Cu1-N1, 1.894(3)Å; Cu1-N2A, 1.888(3)Å; Cu1-O1, 2.534Å; Cu1-O4A, 2.506Å). The Cu(II) ion adopts an octahedral coordination sphere in contrast to the Cu(I) ion. The Cu(II) ion is surrounded by four N atoms from two HPyImDC2- anions, one 1,2-diaminopropane ligand, and two O atoms from two terminal water molecules (Cu2-N4, 2.032Å; Cu2-N3, 2.044Å; Cu2-O1W, 2.533Å). The oxidation states of Cu ions are confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Fig. S3). Furthermore, Cu(I) ions and HPyImDC2- anions are arranged in a line to form 1D chains {-CuI-HPyImDC2--CuI-} (a), and two chains are interconnected by the Cu(II) ions to build a 1D rhombic chains along the [110] direction (b). Inside the chains, π-π interactions exist since the distance between two parallel HPyImDC2- ligands is 3.849Å (c).

The thermal stabilities of compounds 1 and 2 are investigated through TGA experiments in the temperature range of 35-800°C as shown in Fig. S7. An initial weight loss of compound 1 below 150°C can be attributed to the removal of N, N-dimethylformamide on the surface of the compounds. Upon further heating the organic ligand and the ammonium ions start to decompose and exhibit a weight loss of 73.30% between 165 and 393°C (calcd: 75.86%). The final product of 25.86% is attributed to the formation of CuO powder.

For compound 2, the first step weight loss of 3.75% below 273°C can be attributed to the removal of water molecules (calcd: 4.70%). The second weight loss that occurred from 273 to 462°C (68.38%) can be attributed to the decomposition of the 1,2-diaminopropane and the HPyImDC2- ligand (calcd: 70.24%). The final residuals of 30.85% are attributed to the formation of CuO powder.

decomposition temperature.type: decomposition of the organic ligand and the ammonium ions
decomposition of the 1,2-diaminopropane and the HPyImDC2− ligand

metadata.title: Assembly of two Cu-based coordination polymers from 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate ligand
